qas.question: What sub-arctic islands do not have glaciers?
What Australian mountain has a glacier?
What are spreading rapidly in New Guinea?

context: <b5_0>Glaciers<b5_0/> are present on <a1_0>every continent<a1_0/> and approximately <a0_0>fifty<a0_0/> countries, excluding those (Australia, South Africa) that have glaciers only on distant subantarctic island territories. Extensive glaciers are found in Antarctica, Chile, Canada, Alaska, Greenland and Iceland. Mountain glaciers are widespread, especially in the <a2_0>Andes, the Himalayas, the Rocky Mountains, the Caucasus, and the Alps<a2_0/>. Mainland Australia currently contains no glaciers, although a small glacier on <b7_0>Mount Kosciuszko<b7_0/> was present in the last glacial period. In New Guinea, small, rapidly diminishing, <b8_0>glaciers<b8_0/> are located on its highest summit massif of Puncak Jaya. Africa has glaciers on <a3_0>Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania, on Mount Kenya and in the Rwenzori Mountains<a3_0/>. Oceanic islands with glaciers occur on Iceland, Svalbard, New Zealand, Jan Mayen and the subantarctic islands of <a4_0><b6_0>Marion, Heard, Grande Terre (Kerguelen) and Bouvet<b6_0/><a4_0/>. During glacial periods of the Quaternary, Taiwan, Hawaii on Mauna Kea and Tenerife also had large alpine glaciers, while the Faroe and Crozet Islands were completely glaciated.
